column1: content

Well..I "had fixed" the exhaust manifold
, the exhaust-brake tube, a serious fuel leak and the toad brake pump all in one gulp at the shop. Remaining is the drippy water drain discovered at the shop and the dead dash air.
Isn't that enough?

It's always something with these toys. I had the banks power
pack exhaust and headers installed since the MH had broken bolts in the exhaust manifold
. BTW, the Banks is not cheap but best money I ever spent...it's like driving a New motorhome! Installed Koni shocks
, also money well spent. Tuned it up with new plugs, wires, distributor cap
, coil, pvc. 4 New Michelins on the drive axle. New kitchen faucet, upgraded power converter to progressive dynamics unit, and am trying to see why the bedroom reading lamps don't work. Oh, also removed the fuel tank
and cleaned it out and had a shop re-weld the seams due to a leak. That was a pain, especially since it had about 45 gallons of fuel in it and an anti syphon device so couldn't syphon it out. Later I will need to address a leak in one of the rear hydraulic jacks but this is enough for now. Even with my belly aching....I love this MH and I actually enjoy tinkering with it.

Got temp plates on Friday, passed emissions on Friday as well with flying colors. Full clean and detail is ongoing. Rear, front and one side done with the buffer. Buffer is evil i might add. Next Saturday the girl will have new shoes on the rear. Oil and filter changed. Chassis lubed. All good so far.
I've started looking into replacing shocks and airbags. Also looking into steering stabilizers and track bars. Undecided at this point but research is everything

Quote:
Originally Posted by iamblum
I've started looking into replacing shocks and airbags. Also looking into steering stabilizers and track bars. Undecided at this point but research is everything
After looking at them all I decided on the Monroe RV shock and stabilizer. One thing that helped was a 30% discount plus free shipping.
They have to be better then the leaky one that was on it.

Need to replace trombetta solenoid for slides and leveling system! Replaced awning topper on living room slide! Replaced chassis battery's on way home from Florida!
Sent from my iPhone using iRV2 - RV Forum

My wife found a mat that fits our bathroom floor perfectly. stoked about that!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
I know , I know.. not a class A anymore.... dang I hate having nothing to fix...
JUST TEASING, my floor creaks in one spot like crazy though, and my "single stage" charger will COOK my batteries if I leave it on too long....
Just reinstalled the drive belt on my Splendide 2100XC Combo WD. So far so good!

Hmm. Does it count as doing something if you can't get it done ? DH called Frigidare for service on fridge in 2016 Forest River Berkshire. Frigidare cannot dispatch service because the item is not where you registered it from!! They did offer to sell us an extended warranty!? Our first trip since purchase last Sept & waiting for the real fun to begin . Lol

This week--installed Autoformer, replaced the coalescing filter on top of engine, ran wires from batt to wetbay for portable macerator.
DICK

Did you use AC DELCO
plugs? Looking for 10 mm wire.

Replaced the rear shocks
today. Did the front shocks and stabilizer damper last week. Was going to just do the fronts but decided to replace the rears also. Happy that I did as they were shot. The new shocks (Monroe RV ) Look more stout then the originals.

Rebuilt macerator, installed new water pump, greased coach and completed aqua hot servicing. Still need to reseal couple of spots to eliminate intermittent leaks. Then hitting the road for a month and a half.

I replaced the oil cooler
gaskets and seals on my CAT 3126. If you're looking to do something that requires folding your arms and body in ways that aren't humanly possible, I suggest trying it.
On a good note, it no longer hemorrhages oil. 5 gallons of oil from South Carolina to Chicago was my last adventure.
Good times

One of my wife's tactics for getting me to buy her a new mh included "You won't have to do as much maintenance with a new one".
Now the daughter and her husband own our old Bounder and they want to take it on their first vacation trip in a few weeks. The husband is eager to help and learn about their new toy but he is very busy with work at present.
So the guy with less maintenance to tackle is currently handling a complete brake job, which included separating the front hubs from the rotors for new replacement rotors. This will be immediately followed with the task of removing the radiator for a recore. After that is complete I will attend to the replacement of a leaking rear seal on the transmission and will wrap it up with a bevy of small repair items.
Then I will return the Flounder so the daughter can build her nest inside before vacation.

After that is complete I will attend to the replacement of a leaking rear seal on the transmission and will wrap it up with a bevy of small repair items.
Then I will return the Flounder so the daughter can build her nest inside before vacation.
A good RV tech should get at least 40 - 45 an hour. Perhaps a family discount of 10% is in order. LOL.

Tracking down a leak today and found a broken rear shock attachment
Sooo..... I'll be ordering a pair of Bilsteins at $100 each
Like I always say.... If it ain't one thing... its something more expensive
And... I never found the leak

Just finished making some repairs to the condenser fins on my main A/C unit
Here are the before and after pictures
Checked the discharge pressure before & after repair.
70 psig difference.
This equals no more trips on High Head Pressure
Lower Head pressure = Lower Operating Cost
And much easier on the system.
But it took me 2 hours to repair the aluminum fins, hence the before picture it was daylight and the after picture was night time.....hahaha!

Changed engine & genset oil and filters. Flushed both cooling systems and put in Final Charge Global OAT coolant in both. Won't need to do anything other than coolant filter change for 7 years!
Getting ready for first trip this year!
Horay! I am ready!!
Replaced my inverter with a Magnum MS2812, bolt pattern didn't match the Prosine, but all is well and I can now charge the batteries that will need replacement next.
Stopped by the shop today and started the old girl up, also exercised the genny. Close as I have come to actually spending time working on it latelyðŸ˜¢

Replaced the front crankshaft seal
on my Onan generator and repairing my Aquahot. Need to recharge the a/c and wash the coach.

Quote:
Originally Posted by Dave-Oh
when my furnace did that, it turned out that the propane regulator
was bad. If your stove won't support more than one burner and the flame has a lot of orange/yellow, it may be the regulator.
The three burners all have blue flame. So back to checking the furnace. I have not had time to check it out yet, but eventually I will have to tackle that problem. Right now I have been using the heat pumps. Thanks for the tip though.

Well,
For starters, I change oil on the big beast, 19 qts and a filter, no issues. But, the really big deal is, I changed the QD 7500 fuel filter
WITHOUT GETTING FUEL ALL OVER THE PLACE as has been reported by many on here and other RV forums. It did drip a few drops but, I was ready for that. So, to me, this was a great victory. Now, on to other maintenance for our upcoming trip.
Scott

Today I removed my Carefree slide out cover, and reversed it so the small tear was wrapped around the roller where it wouldn't show, instead of attached to the side of the mh where it flapped in the breeze.

Well....I always seem to be doing something minor just to spend time with the RV. My latest fix was modifying the circuit board tray for my Precision Temp tankless hot water heater. Seems if we had a hard blowing rain, water would get in the tray that both circuit boards sit in. Once wet, the system would not function. Don't like doing without hot water !! So I drilled a couple of holes in the bottom of the tray to drain away any water, raised the circuit board about 3/8 of an inch by putting plastic spacers between the bottom of the tray and the circuit board and siliconed the rivets to ensure water was not getting in through them. I'm hoping this fixed my problem!!
Thanks !!
Hhg

The last couple days I spent replacing the older flat panel TV with a new LED flat panel. I replaced it for a couple of reasons, one was size, 32" ver. 40" but that wasn't the main reason main reason was weight 35lbs. ver. 14lbs. but I do have to admit size does matter.

Just got ours out of the shop. The Xantrax controller and power distribution circuit board were improperly wired at the factory. Had that fixed but had to replace all four house batteries. Added an ice maker to make life a little nicer. Had the propane orifice on the fridge cleans so fridge would run on propane when needed.

Replaced 2 air brake valves, one Rx12 (I think) and obesity above it and am now seeking a 3rd. Presently tracing an electrical labyrinth that David Bowie would be mesmerized with to figure why nothing is holding a charge anymore. Gotta be a bad diode somewhere...!
My domestic fridge. Was giving me a code with no flame. Opened up the access and blew it out with my mouth to see if that was it. Heard it "woof" a few times, so I blew harder and it fired up

I did a full brake job on my 1999 F53. All calipers and brackets. All 5 rubber hoses. Not a fun job for a 75 year old. also replaced all four valve stems on the rear tires to get rid of the troulesome extenders. I love the long stems. No longer have to use a truck gauge or chuck to service tires. Any auto air chuck or gauge will work on the tires now.

Quote:
Originally Posted by iamblum
My domestic fridge. Was giving me a code with no flame. Opened up the access and blew it out with my mouth to see if that was it. Heard it "woof" a few times, so I blew harder and it fired up
You might want to go on the Dometic website and enter your Model/Serial number to see if there are any recalls. Mine had one that the Newmar dealer performed at No Charge.
The convection feature on our convection/microwave decided to stop working so a new one is on it's way. Should be here Tuesday.
Replaced engine to frame groundstrap. Had erratic starting problems. Found strap corroded and connection points faulty.

I replaced the Chassis or Engine batteries earlier this year. Just finished replacing the old 24 inch tube Sony TV with a 32 inch LED flatscreen. After removing the wood trim that was around the old TV the new TV just fit in the cabinet. I had to make and install new trim around it. Old TV was 81 lbs and new one is 11 lbs. Now having to add some new tools to offset the weight loss so the front tires
stay on the ground (hehe!!)

Originally Posted by dutchstr3884
I replaced the Chassis or Engine batteries earlier this year. Just finished replacing the old 24 inch tube Sony TV with a 32 inch LED flatscreen. After removing the wood trim that was around the old TV the new TV just fit in the cabinet. I had to make and install new trim around it. Old TV was 81 lbs and new one is 11 lbs. Now having to add some new tools to offset the weight loss so the front tires
stay on the ground (hehe!!)
I sure would like to see pictures of how the new 32" fit in the box and how it looks after it is all finished. I would like to replace mine one of these days, but have not found a TV that is square, most are rectangular.

Quote:
Originally Posted by RayChez1
I sure would like to see pictures of how the new 32" fit in the box and how it looks after it is all finished. I would like to replace mine one of these days, but have not found a TV that is square, most are rectangular.
My TV replacement is in progress. The pictures are how I am mounting the TV to fit in a larger sized opening. It will be hinged at the top and have locks at the bottom. This will allow me access to the wiring and also I am installing shelves so the space can be used for storage.
The frame shown is for mock up purposes only. I am in the process of building the real one out of Cherry wood which will be stained to matching the existing cabinet.

Quote:
Originally Posted by Rsponsford
What product should be used to coat the fiberglass roof? Mine needs to be done.
Rsponsford,
Just wondering, why do you think you need to coat a fiberglass roof? Most of us with fiberglass roofs just wash them and, put an occasional coat of wax on them. Just wondering.
Scott

Removed and cleaned the MAF sensor
, and cleared the code to turn off the check engine light. Plan on taking it out for a drive over the weekend to see if that solved the problem. If not then I guess it's time for a new MAF. It didn't LOOK dirty, but I don't know how much (or how little) crud it takes to cause it to throw a code.
Thanks to Roger and everyone in the Workhorse Chassis forum I was able to replace the Rotten Green Switch and Light Switch on my Autopark Brake on my 2000 Winnebago Adventurer 32V.

While getting ready for our first trip with our new to us MH she was loaded up and ready to go in the morning. Ahh a month in the Florida Keys.
So I thought i'd spray some silicone on the slide rails before i brought them back in. I notice something strange just inside the right front slide. My flashlight and a magnetic thingy rod and out comes a washer, lock washer and 3/8 nut. Oh no whats broke now before our maiden voyage. Upon further investigation i see where at the end of the slide rail where it attaches to the slide one bolt is missing it's nut, washer and lock washer and one is missing bolt and everything and the rest are extremely loose.
I checked all the rest and got at least 3 to 4 complete turns on the nuts for the remaining. Boy does that slide run smooth now.
Later on i'll remove the nuts and put some blue lock tight on em.
DW returned as i was wrenching em and thought oh no what now.
All is good for now

A backing nut came off my air conditioner control on my dash panel
, found it with a mirror and put back on. Somehow feel this was the easy fix.

Onan 7000 generator was hard to start, vacuum choke would stay on , if choke was opened up by hand, engine seem to run not too bad. After a minute noticed one cylinder was cold. Spark plug
was OK, Spark Ok. Removed rocker cover for that cylinder and found a broken rocker for intake valve. When I replaced the rocker I found the rocker stud was loose and had rotated out several turns out of the cylinder head
. Checked the 3 other rockers , they where all loose as where all the other rocker studs. Tightened studs, adjusted valve clearances and generator has been good since then.

On maiden voyage realized alt wasn't charging so I had to jump the house and engine batteries to make it home. When it got home I put in the shop and got dash ac charged, steering box adjusted and all fluids/filters changed incl one in air system. Took it on 2400 round trip and dash air went warm and frig was at 70F so back in the shop so hopefully can take it to Oshkosh at the end of the month.
New air brake chambers on the back wheels and new diaphragms on the front wheels also pulled the drivers side window to repair a water leak then did a chassis lube, last week was a busy one.

Our door power awning
stopped working. I determined the awning shaft that attaches to the motor stripped so I disassembled it and put in a set screw to lock them together. Works like new now.

Our 1989 Rexhall Airex has been a good learning machine. Lots of big and little repairs.
It ran well when we bought it but last year it started backfiring when you took your foot off the gas, and using twice as much gas. Ran awful so we parked it. Local mechanics took my money for tuneups but no improvement. Its a Ford 460
fuel injected engine so I went on the Ford 460
forum for a few months. Finally got an old guy who knew the engine. He said to replace the fuel pressure regulator
and idle control valve
. Presto! A wonderful sweet running engine.
It has a Ford chassis and we had the famous ignition key linkage break in the steering column
. This is identified when you go to start the engine, feel a snap when you turn the key, and the key now rotates completely around with no resistence. This requires pulling the steering wheel and tearing the column apart. Lots of tricks. This is common with Fords of this era so fotunately there are lots of excellent you tube videos.
The water heater leaked when we pressurized it this spring. I pulled it out but it was a rusty wreck, not repairable. Went through a long song and dance to find the right replacement but thanks to one knowledgeable RV tech we got one that works.
Continuing to replace all the lights with LED's as I find them on sale.
DonM

Replaced rear Air Springs and shocks.....Fronts are next.....
Wasn't too bad hour and a half it was completed...

Replaced the pawls on our 2008 tow dolly
ratchets.
Back Coleman Mach 8 AC wasn't working and compressor was moaning in pain! Replaced both the START and the RUN capacitor and it runs like a dream. Thank you Amazon Prime!

Just finished major service, oil, filter, lube chassis, air filter, fuel filter
, trans pan drain and in line filter, and major genny service.
Added 5 star tune to top things off.

Learning about how a microwave/convection oven works. Preheated as convection, temp reached and I placed a frozen chicken pie on the glass turntable. Sitting outside for a few minutes when we hear loud crashing/explosive sound. Hmm. Grandson jumping around? After the second or 3rd loud noise we went in and realized it was the oven. Turned it off, and when we opened the glass tray was in several lovely wedge shaped pieces. So, out to dinner, found the part number & ordered from Amazon. Lesson learned, don't forget to put the metal rack in oven for convection cooking! ( or hot glass frozen food do not play well together!)

Well after reading thru this thread I figured I needed to join in. Bought a 2008 Tour Master T40c in mid-June as a trade for our 2008 Hurricane 31H gasser. I really wished I had looked it over more carefully. :-(
Lots of little foibles to fix. The unit has 3 sets of batteries, 2 12v chassis, 2 12v house, and 4 6v house for the inverter stuff like a residential fridge. Dealer said the 4 6v ones were bad and was replacing them for us but didn't have any 6v on hand so put in 4 12v ones wired appropriately. Turns out those were not the house batteries that were bad. Moved 2 of them to the main house area to replace the 2 bad 12v ones there and buying 4 new 6v for the front this week like it should have. At least now the main house 12v works and I can operate lites and other stuff in it.
Door check strap was not working properly so I have that all apart trying to fabricate a fix for it.
Door keyless entry
was not functioning and I just found that it may be just a fuse. (not likely from my experience so far)
I have a "water in fuel" warning about 100 miles from the dealer driving it home, but there is no water coming out of the separator so I think either the sensor or filter in it may be bad.
While under the front dealing with batteries I noticed the inside of both front wheels are "wet" so I will be doing inner wheel bearing
seals very soon since I need to get it inspected which will also mean replacing brake shoes
.
Anode rod is shot and have new one coming today. Need to flush the HW
tank as well.
And, before we even use it, the wife wants to paint the walls, cabinets and put down new flooring so we have all the doors off and in the garage right now.
Don't get wrong, I'd rather have these issues than have kept the Hurricane. It had its own set of problems that I really didn't want to tackle.
We might get to use it before snow flies. :-)
Scott

Congrats on your TourMaster coach. We had several in our Club and they had Mercedes engines which were very good and powerful engines. It seems like most of the stuff you have to fix are regular maintenance on any motor home
. Like the anodes, they need to be changed out every year. Fact I just done mine on a Suburban ten gallon tank. Got the part through Amazon for thirteen bucks (magnesium) type.
The painting of the cabinets is what is hard for me to imagine why so soon. I have the Walnut wood on mine and we just love it.
The battery thing is also hard to figure out why the dealer would replace six volt batteries with twelve volt batteries. It will work if hooked up properly, but the thing is that deep cycle six volt batteries are much better for the house part. Twelve volt for the chassis, cranking of the engine is just fine.
Best of luck with your new coach.

I dropped the roof panel of my Coleman Mach unit to try and identify any hot to cool leaks. There is an insulated piece of foam that separates the two sides. I used some duct tape in the cold side to improve the seal. There are only two warm air intakes, both about 2" x 3", that are supposed to feed air to the system. That seems quite inadequate. Any known solutions to increase the return air?

"off" is the best place for wheel covers
.
that goes for Valve core extenders, as well

Quote:
Originally Posted by Deny
"off" is the best place for wheel covers
.
that goes for Valve core extenders, as well
Totally agree! Mine never left the dealer. I tossed the extenders and replaced them with gator caps. You can check and inflate the tire without removing them but they seal the valve stem.
They're a buck apiece from any truck tire shop.
Given the price of RV tires
and the risk of damage from tire failure, I'm a pressure fanatic.

Quote:
Originally Posted by AITG
Totally agree! Mine never left the dealer. I tossed the extenders and replaced them with gator caps. You can check and inflate the tire without removing them but they seal the valve stem.
thanks to you guys for the post about the gators. i'd never heard of them before so I did a quick search, understood the concept and ordered from Amazon. They'll be here tomorrow for the motorhome and both of our cars.
Lubed slide seals, and slide gears

Replaced a broken shear pin on my main slideout today at the campground.Was getting ready to leave and running slideouts in the main one quit half the way in.Went out and checked the mechanism and the pin had broken ,replaced with a grade 8 bolt and nut and was on my way.Took about 10 mins. as I have done this before ,Camping World says there is nothing wrong withe slideout but it has broken about 6 pins sine I have had this unit.

Originally Posted by 06georgieboy
Replaced a broken shear pin on my main slideout today at the campground.Was getting ready to leave and running slideouts in the main one quit half the way in.Went out and checked the mechanism and the pin had broken ,replaced with a grade 8 bolt and nut and was on my way.Took about 10 mins. as I have done this before ,Camping World says there is nothing wrong withe slideout but it has broken about 6 pins sine I have had this unit.
You might rethink using a hardened bolt in your slide out drive.
Sometimes shearing a bolt saves a more expense part.

Finally replaced the Lift Pump on my 8.3 ISC Cummins....stripped the threads on a banjo fitting. Had to get a second replacement pump. This time also ordered ang got new gasket for original pump, to repair and keep on standby.

Quote:
Originally Posted by 06georgieboy
Replaced a broken shear pin on my main slideout today at the campground.Was getting ready to leave and running slideouts in the main one quit half the way in.Went out and checked the mechanism and the pin had broken ,replaced with a grade 8 bolt and nut and was on my way.Took about 10 mins. as I have done this before ,Camping World says there is nothing wrong withe slideout but it has broken about 6 pins sine I have had this unit.
I know exactly what you are going thru as our last coach was a 2006 Georgie Boy Pursuit. The first day when were got home with our new to us MH the front driver side slide wouldn't go in, motor worked but no slide movement. Looking under the slide to see what was going on i saw other pieces of broken shear pins of various types. I used a bolt for the temporary fix. Thought okay this is probably why i got such a good deal as the previos owner wasn't as handy.
One of the broken pins looked like a roll pin which i couldnt find in any stores so i got a 1/4" SS clevis pin. I bought several just in case. That broke again some time later. The second pin i put in i removed after the 6th use to see whats going on and it was bent and would soon break. I took a 1/4 drill bit to clean up where the pin went, put a new one in without having to use a hammer and punch and at the 6th slide use i just pushed the old one out with the new one. Only took a few minutes. I was concerned what would happen if the pin would break when the slide was almost in, that would be a very difficult repair.
It didn't take long to use up my supply of pins and started a search. I found a manufacture of quality SS pins at pivotpins.com. Only catch was their $35 minium order. I had a supply to last a lifetime. The 1/4 pins i bought had the small hole in the end where i put a cotter pin in so it wouldnt fall out. When we traded in that GB all i could pass along to the potential owner was the pins i had in the coach. Somewhere in my garage i will eventually find that bag of pins.
Over the 5 years of owning the GB every time we met another GB owner they would ask if i had a problem with the slide. I would say yes and tell them my work around. This was most likely an under engineered design subject to fail.

Added two large quiet fans to the upper vent of my fridge (external).
Drilled a hole through the fridge from the outside to accommodate 12 volt wiring from a small interior fin fan for the frig as well. I had the wiring for the fin fan routed down the condensate drain line, but it was obstructing the draining action.

While on my trip (Seattle to HB, Ca.) I had a trans slip issue start up while on the last leg of the pass just south of Ashland, Oregon. After cresting the RV would not go beyond 30-35mph. Pull off at Yreka, Ca. stayed the night (Baxters Auto lot).
The next morning they sent me over to Onarheim truck repair. Mechanic checked what I had checked (fluid) which was perfect no issue. he also drove it without issue. Says it may have gotten hot.
Continue on south. Made it to HB, Ca. (shot over from the 5 to the 101 via 505 - 680 - 101). No issue.
On the return trip ~10 days later just south of Willits, Ca. (after a pass) I had it do the same thing again. This was after driving without issue from just north of San Louis Obisbo.
Same results next morning no issue. However roughly 35 later same issue popped up. This time I could tell the trans was in limp mode. Not going from 2-3. Quickly realizing that when turning of the engine and restarting it resets and all is ok. Now beginning to look like shift solenoid issue. Did this (3) until I reached Grants Pass, Oregon and stopped the night. Ended up staying just outside of Jerry's Clutch & Transmission (Great guy). While stopped I used paper clip to pull codes 68 and 87.
The following morning (Joe) mechanic used computer and pulled same codes:
68 - Trans slip
87 - Shift solenoid stuck open
He quickly fixed it by stating the 68 slip can be resolved by turning the force valve up 1/4 turn and we'll replace both shift solenoids A & B.
While we had the RV up on rack he also found that the trans wire connector was leaking as well. Replaced it with upgraded one. Back on the road in roughly 2-3 hours. $290
So if anyone ever has trans issue I highly recommend Jerry's clutch & transmission in Grants Pass, Or.

Quote:
Originally Posted by Radacravitz
what type of roof were you painting?
what we're your criteria in selecting your paint / material?
the reason i'm asking is because i'd like to remove the unnecessary parts from our roof, dicor / eternabond and waterproof as best as possible. i've been leaning toward henry tropicool as the seal but am interested in hearing about your decision process.
tia
Tia, I have a fiberglass roof on my coach. As a member of the Beaver Ambassador Club I took the advice of the multiple members there who have used this same method to clean and restore the roof. I am very confident this roof finish will last a very long time. I believe if you go to the Beaver Ambassador Club web page and look under the technical support tab down a ways you will see complete instructions on "How to"
As for removing the old dicor on the roof I found a multitool with a scraper worked very well. quick and easy to get rid of the old build up, no damage to the fiberglass at all.
Good luck

Quote:
Originally Posted by CoachStreamr
Do you have any pictures of the vents with eternabond tape? I'm curious how the hinge for the vent's hood was handled.
.
CoachStreamr, I did not use eternabond tape on the vent hinges. Only used that to cover the various small holes in the roof from the old CB and Satellite stuff I removed. Used Dicor on the vents.

Quote:
Originally Posted by Golfer Guy
CoachStreamr, I did not use eternabond tape on the vent hinges. Only used that to cover the various small holes in the roof from the old CB and Satellite stuff I removed. Used Dicor on the vents.
I see, so no eternabond around the perimeter of the vent, correct?
I have a Thread linked below where I asked about this. Seems that many do Dicor, wait 24 hours then EternaBond tape around the vents but I'm not sure how they handled the vent hinge (front side of vent)...
http://www.irv2.com/forums/f258/appl...ml#post3777338
I'm going to take more of the old Dicor off and clean then apply new Dicor today or tomorrow. Have the EternaBond tape and roller here but confused on the vent hinge.
I replaced a few of the rusty head screws with new SS #8 1". Have one screw that doesn't want to seat all the way so probably will use a #8 3/4" in that hole. Probably didn't need to replace them and maybe it wasn't wise.

Quote:
Originally Posted by PulShrk
I would like some of your knowledge on fixing the faulty turn signal
in my 1998 Damon intruder. Curious if you can give me a quick run on what to grab and get that knocked out?? If not. No worries.
I'm not familiar with your model coach but my coach is on a Gillig chassis and I bought the replacement switch assembly from Gillig. The part is made from a nylon plastic which I believe is true for all makes and model vehicles. The tab which returns the turn signal
lever to the neutral position after completing a left turn had broken and I would have to manually return the lever to the middle (off) position.
If you have a switch to turn off your air horns then turn them off first. The, remove the horn button
to expose the steering wheel bolts and the large center nut. My steering wheel is mounted with three allen head bolts. After removal of the steering wheel I removed the center nut which holds a backing plate in place. You will then need a steering wheel/hub pulling tool and three of the same thread sized bolts as the allen head bolts but longer. The tool can probably be bought at any auto parts
store and may, or may not, come with the bolts you will need. Before removing the hub use a Sharpie or similar to mark the position relative to the steering shaft so that your steering will be reinstalled in the same position at reassembly. You will then have access to the switch assembly. Disconnect and remove the assembly. The wires go down along the column. If your wires don't have a plug you have to cut and splice the new wires into place. if your coach doesn't already have a switch to turn off the air horns then this is a good opportunity to install one. Mine did not have a switch and more than once the horn was blown at a less than ideal time. (I blame my kids.) put everything back together and you should be good to go.
Hope this helps.

Last trip we picked up a thump at low speed on a smooth road after running down a gravel road. Today I jacked up all four corners to inspect the tires. Everything is fine. While I was under, I re-inspected every line I could find. Ended up re-locating an anti-wear pad on the left front frame rail that protects the power steering
lines, pushing a nylon wire clamp into it's proper location and clamping down the right front brake line
. That one I found by feel-it's on the back side of the front crossmember
.
303d the tires, adjusted air pressures and called it a morning.

My Cummins 400HP Diesel ISL has a plastic radiator tank. I heard that these tanks have had issues with leaks at the neck from cracking. Some people are custom building and changing them to stainless steel. Looking at mine, the tank is in good shape, however the factory overflow tube which is a thin wall vinyl type was pinched right at the radiator cap
connection, and also down the line it was pinched further by wire ties. Could imagine that when the tank needs to overflow this could cause over pressurization which could crack the tank.
I replaced this 1/2" hose with some braided vinyl tubing. No restrictions now!

Headed to Daytona Beach from Atlanta. Decided to stay a couple of nights in Savannah and enjoy the seafood. Two days later ready to leave. Steps will not come up. Disassembled step gearbox and lubed and steps started working. Spent six days at my daughters. Ready to leave and she runs to motorhome and says, Dad, There is something coming out of the motorhome. I think it is transmission fluid
. Raise the hood and find that battery acid has been dripping onto the transmission cooling lines and has eaten a hole in one line and the other line is about worn through. I climbed under the coach and looked at the lines. There are several bends in them. No way could you remove the lines without dropping the engine brace and the radiator. First thought is to install a rubber hose and clamps over the bad spot. Since the end of the tubing was not beveled, It would be easy for the hose to come off. I went to O'Rielly Auto Parts
and found a replacement tube. Went to a auto repair shop and had the pieces bent to conform to the tubing I had cut off. Installed with brass compression fittings. Looks great. On the way home, Steps quit working and light in kitchen stopped working. Kitchen light was easy, just a burned out tube. I remembered a customer had given me a single Kwickee Step. It was new in box. I removed the gearbox, controller, and motor. Installed them on my steps. Now I have all new workings. Just the metal steps themselves are original.

cleaned both roof ac condenser coils today, using the nu-calgon no rinse cleaner.
but i vacuumed them first, then sprayed the solution, waited 15 minutes sprayed the coils with hot water from a spray bottle.
repeated the solution again, rinsed one more time and used a soft tooth brush to clean the drain pain area and added one pan-tab in the drain pan to stop the growth of gunk
re-assembled the interior cover and let em rip...
Evap Pow'r-C evaporator coil cleaner

Well the first thing I had to do was replace my chassis batteries in the spring as they were toast, maint. free batteries, broke the caps off and they were dry as a bone!! Who puts maint. free batteries in an RV?? I put an ounce of mineral oil in each cell of the new batteries to help prevent gassing off, it works! Then I changed oil and filter (full synthetic Amsoil) changed fuel filter
and installed shut off valves on the inlet and outlet side to make changing the fuel filter
easier in the future. Serviced the trans, new filters and Amsoil full synthetic as well. Changed rear end oil to you guessed it Amsoil 75-90 severe gear full synthetic, changed the oil in my front wheel bearings
to the Amsoil synthetic as well, then greased "Everything" with Amsoil grease. (can you tell I love Amsoil products? my buddy is an Amsoil dealer) I had both rear inner dual tire valve stems replaced because when I put the Eeze TPMS system on I had issues with leaks. Replaced my coach water pump with a better higher flow pump and it works awesome! I also had to install anti billowing devices on my kitchen / living room slide and bed room slide as we were coming back form Saskatchewan in strong cross winds and it parachuted my kitchen slide topper out, had to crawl up on the roof and clamp some vice grips on it to stop it. Then the fun stuff, the outside was looking shabby so I had to repaint some of the stripes as the stripes are painted over a gel coat finish, not full paint. The stealership where we bought it in Arizona tried to buff the road side to make it shine but all they did was cut down the clear coat over the stripes so now they are pealing. Then scrubbed the whole unit down and put about 10 coats of ZEP on it, I know a lot of people on here don't like ZEP but up here in Canada we don't have the intense sun like the southern states so it work just fine up here, I still plan on putting a good UV protecting wax on top of it to help protect it and then give it a few coats of ZEP every spring to stay ahead of it. for a 2004 coach it looks like new! This past Wednesday I installed a new water filter for our drinking water as the old one was hard to get filters for and also installed a water filter on the inlet for the "Whole House" so all the water gets filtered. I am very fussy about my vehicles and don't want to have a break down so I do everything in my power to prevent that from happening. It's just the mechanic in me I guess........... One last thing I want to do is change all my rad hoses and flush the cooling system, have the hoses just need the time and weather to do it! Well I'm done, a bit long winded but this was my summer, camping as much as we could between working on the coach as well as going to weddings! We've been busy! Have a great day!

Purchased a TPMS for it and toad. Should be here Wednesday. Then thought I would check the tire pressures. Fronts were down about 10lbs. Aired them up. Then wire brushed some rust off my LP tank. Put on some Rustoleum rust stop. Tomorrow I will top coat it with some Rustoleum white.

We left the coach with Cummins Hilliard Monday morning at 7 am.
We picked it up yesterday, Friday at 2 pm as they drove it out of the bay.
The issue, a leaking exhaust manifold gasket
.
But when the manifold was removed. They found lots of pitting and wanted me to have it replaced also.
It's all apart replace it. That's a no brainier in my opinion. And it was the original 17 year old manifold.
Two bolt's extracted.
The two rear ones. To much heat maybe.
I had them split the turbo and inspect. It was A ok.
And while it's apart.
Pulled the valve cover
and do the 100,000 mile valve adjustment tune up.
No valves needed adjusting.
A new air filter was also installed.
In all reality I could have run several years with the slight leak.
For the miles I drive annually.
But it's done now and they gave me a one year or 100 thousand miles warranty.
So that was the project for early October 2017.
And, a big thanks to the guys at Cummins Hilliard
For keeping me posted and for doing a professional Job.
If you're in the Columbus Ohio area and you need work done on a Cummins or your Onan.
Check them out.
The private shop that I use in Delaware was 4 weeks waiting and I had a schedule to keep.
Cummins got me in with a week's notice.

After being puzzled over the error on my fridge when trying to run it on gas and the hot water heater going into lockout while on gas when they are obviously both firing up. I had a close look at the stove burner and realized the crackling and whump sound at shut off meant something was amiss at the propane tank.
Replaced the regulator and hose and all better now. Glad I kept it simple. I had all kinds of ideas in my head of repairs on the fridge and water heater.
On my Tire Minder TPMS transmitters i replaced all batteries, caps and O ring seals for the MH and toad.

Finally...got the water heater to function on gas. When we first got the coach it worked fine. Then It was erratic and then wouldn't fire. I replaced the LP regular last week and it resolved the erratic gas flow and the gas issue with my other LP appliances. Last night while driveway camping due to power out from winds and storms I got the water heater to function by reseating the connectors. I thought I had it fixed after changing out the regulator. I think I will order and ECO stat just in case. looks pretty simple to replace and not terribly expensive. Looks like this one has been in here a while.

When I installed my residential fridge,
1. I installed a separate 120v outlet on a switch so that I could easily turn the unit off when not needed without going outside to pull the plug (some units do not have an on/off switch).
2. I chose not to seal off the existing outside openings. I put a screen on the lower opening and installed 3ea. 12v fans in the upper vent to assure good air circulation. I used the 12v wiring from the old Norcold and put the fans on a separate switch with a thermostat so they were not running all the time.
3. I then trimmed around the perimeter of the fridge with black plastic L channel which I purchased from Display Products online ( Extrusions by Display Products Online). This can be purchased with the tape already attached.

.

My installed macerator pump
blew the fuse. I found it was very hard to turn. I removed the pump and disassembled it. The first thing I found was 2 of the 4 long screws that hold the cover on and the impeller housing to the motor were sheared off and laying in the inlet hose. Second thing was the cutter blade was jammed with hair. The repair kit consisting of the impeller, impeller housing and gaskets is $89. The 4 brass screws are $19. The 2 screws that were sheared screwed into the impeller housing into brass inserts. The other 2 screws go through the the impeller housing and screw into the motor. The motor is tapped for all 4 screws but only 2 screw into the motor.
I drilled out the broke screws and inserts. I made 2 new screws from 10 32 brass rod and 2 gaskets from heavy paper. I cleaned the hair from the cutter blade. I reassembled the macerator with all 4 screws screwed into the motor. I reinstalled it and it works great. Total cost $6 for 2 ft of 10 32 brass rod.
I added clean macerator to my January todo list.

Quote:
Originally Posted by Harricat55
Our Atwood electric/propane hot water heater would not heat water using electric mode. I read that the element had probably went bad so this weekend I changed it out. This was not a difficult job if you pull the hot water tank out completely. The element was caked in calcium and rust but what was disturbing the electrical wiring connected to the element had gotten so hot that it had melted one of the wire nuts breaking the connection . So I replace the element and the relay and cleaned up all of the wiring and I now have hot water using the electric mode. My question if anyone knows, 'would the calcium buildup cause a short causing the wiring to basically fry?'.
Wiring probably burned from a bad connection calcium build up will not short out Element

Quote:
Originally Posted by Adoyle52
Wiring probably burned from a bad connection calcium build up will not short out Element
I donâ€™t mean to disagree with you but calcium buildup can and will lead to element failure. The calcium will cause corrosion to form between the metal casing around the heating element allowing pinholes to form. Water then gets into the insulator and grounds the element. After the element shorts inside the water heater it will cause the amperage to increase to the point it burns the wire terminals
. Calcium buildup can also damage the element by acting as an insulation around the outside of the element. This results in damage to the element and again my result in failure.

Some years back, I took my RV, with a 454, in with a piston slap noise. They replaced the piston, all right, with the wrong piston...said I needed a full rebuild.
I parked it for 6 months, then took the engine out myself, the rebuilder told me the issue. The mechanic denied the issue, I just put it all back together & moved on. At least, my rig was ready to travel.
Hard piped my Thetford Sanicon Turbo dump line to exterior underside of coach.

On our last trip I could smell a little propane near the propane compartment every once in a while. I put soapy water on all the connections and all was good. When we returned home we winterized.
A couple of days ago I opened the propane valve and again smelled propane near the tank. This time I had the time and proper leak detecting fluid and went to work. I uncovered the regulator again and repositioned it so I could see and test the front of it and found my leak.
These cheap regulators are crimped to hold them together. That is where the leak was.
So, I went on a search for a new regulator in town. Just so happens my friend is in the auction/salvage business and when I stopped by his place he had a new one on hand from a sale of RV dealership. It was a direct replacement and all is good!!
Patrick

Put a new furnace in my old 93 Brave. Had sprung a water leak and while repairing the leak pulled the old furnace out for access and cleaning and found almost the entire bottom was rusted out. That new furnace makes it TOASTY in there now! Fairly easy swap to do for a newbie.
Removed the front bumpstops and replaced them with SumoSprings (SSF-186-40). May go out for a test drive / regular exercise run tomorrow.

During our last trip I noticed a knock from down below when the steering wheel was turned a bit past off center. Every thing felt solid and not far from home so we got home safe. Had my wife rock the steering wheel back and forth while I peeked past the left front tire to see what moved where before I started crawling around underneath. My eyes widened when I saw the steering box shifting back and forth against the frame rail. The three 3/4" nylock nuts were loose! Thankfully, the nuts and bolt heads were easy enough to get sockets on and torqued to spec. Knocking gone, knocking on wood it won't knock again. Add another item to periodic checklist.
2015 Newmar Ventana, 18k miles.

What I finally got fixed was a warranty issue that took almost 8 months to figure out. So if any of you are experiencing the following description on your Thor 33.2 2017 Palazzo the here is one possible solution. Since I drove away from the dealer with my brand new Palazzo last year in April, my coach kept showing issues at start up and then again once I got started with messages of problems with the coach. All of the warning lights would suddenly come on and the coach would die. Now this is not good especially if you were on the interstate at 65 mph. The other warning that came on was a transmission communication error and the coach would die. Five visits and multiple phone calls to the local and South Carolina manufacturing site for Freightliner they finally figured out the Europe codes, the shift pad was shorting out and causing the coach to lose communication with the transmission and for some unknown reason kill the engine. So if you have a Palazzo and these issues come to light have them check the shift pad first and you might be able to avoid 8 months of not using your coach vs the fun of using it!
John

This is why at the age of 50 ( a few years ago) I left field service and now sit on my fat backside and help people tech over the phone. Its actually way more stressful but my body couldn't take equipment repair, installation and removal any more.

I used to have some drill bits
that would cut through stainless like it was soft steel. I had some hack saw blades that would cut easily.
Sure wish I had the source for those now. Seems all I can find is junk these days.

I've got a HF Saws All that cost me under $15 when you figure it was on sale and with a 20% coupon. Been at least 10 years and It's still going strong.
You're absolutely correct on the blades both for hacksaws and the Saws All. I have been using the Portland or Milwaukee brand blades from HD or Lowe's
. I also remember my friends telling me about the bi-metal blades. Not sure who made them or what they did to make them work so well but they did.
As with all things like drill bits
or saw blades that take all the abuse and do all the real work and it pays to buy the best quality you can find. The cutters you get with HF stuff may last about 30 seconds on anything but wood or plastic.
Very seldom (almost never) did I find any "Eazy- Out" that worked. I called them Hard- Outs.
Always told my students, "If you grab the Vice-Grips first you've lost the battle. Found very few uses for the VG's. Good to hold some things but lousy for removing nuts or bolts.
The same is true for the standard slip-joint pliers. I have one pair and they are maybe used once a year. The jaws are so short they won't fit around my wood stain stored in plastic gallon jugs (Grape Juice containers). So I reach for the Channel-Lock brand of slip joint pliers. The longer jaws do make their use a bit more practical. I probably use mine 2 to 3 times a week.
Most any tool has a place in my tool box but some are so seldom used still not sure why I keep them. I guess it''s for the one time a year that they earn their keep.

The best tool to use on frozen screws is a manual handheld Impact Driver and plenty of PB Blaster. It will only move the screws 1/4" but that's usually enough.

Hey Tim,
Well, at present, I think I have no less than about 20+ pairs of pliers in my tool box. 5-6 pairs of vise grips (some are burnt from holding close proximity joints for welding), some small (about 4" long needle nosed vice trips and blunt nosed ones too), gas or regular pliers, BIG BERTHA or, otherwise known as the largest pair of channel lock type pliers made by Craftsman, cutters of all types and sizes, wire strippers of all types and sizes and specialty pliers for specific purposes. I've used vice grips for all my life. Yep, they have their place in the mechanical world but, usually not the first in line up of what to use.
As for penetrating oil, well, 65 now and, been been wrenching ever since I was oh, probably around 12 or so and, as of yet, I've NEVER, EVER had a penetrating oil work for me. I've tried pretty much everyone that's been made. I've soaked things for 3-4 days and, no luck. Some folks have had luck with penetrating oils but, not me. The most recent case for me was the infamous fan hub bearing replacement for our C-7 330 CAT. CAT, in it's infinite wisdom, decided that four, Allen head, flat head, metric 6MM or 7mm screws would hold the fan serpentine pulley onto the fan hub. Well, in order to get that fan hub off, you have to get those Allen head screws out.
Well, after quite a bit of time screwing around with every method known to man, trying to break them free, I said the hell with it and, hit them with something stronger than they were. A DRILL BIT! That did the trick. I had all four off, and the pulley, in about 2-3 minutes. Should have done that in the first place. Live and learn.
As for cutting blades for sawzalls etc., I've been using "Lennox" blades from Lowes. They are white in color and, without a doubt, some of the strongest blades and, long lasting blades, I've seen yet. I've used some that I should have worn out long before they did. A tad costly but, well worth it if you tackle harder jobs now and then.
Scott

While we're dealing with broken fasteners, here's a couple of tricks. First, left handed drill bits
are nice to have if you can find them. When they bite into the screw they sometimes screw the broken chunk out.
Second, I have had far more success with using a 10 inch pipe wrench than I ever did with Vise Grips. The pipe wrench continues to tighten on the bolt as you turn it so it doesn't slip.

Quote:
Originally Posted by Pigman1
Splendide Aristan TVM63X clothes drier. Our clothes drier had become so loud when operating that it was almost impossible to hear the front TV. On a stop at Tiffin service, their people diagnosed the problem as a bad motor causing the noise. They were willing to pull the drier and replace it (for a cost of about $650 for a new drier), however, they did not have a new motor. I asked them to remove the drier and place it in my pickup, which they did for a cost of less than $50. When I got home, I disassembled the unit and removed the motor. There was no doubt that the motor bearings were gone. I disassembled the motor and pulled the bearings. A trip to Kaman Industrial Technologies got me 2 new ball bearings for less than $10. Reassembly took about an hour and I'll reinstall the unit in the Bus with the help of my grandson tomorrow. It runs like a top and very quiet. Spent $10---Saved $650.
Great post and thanks much. I intend to repair mine next month and will follow your lead. I sent you a PM.
This is one noisy dryer!

Quote:
Originally Posted by pduggs
Great post and thanks much. I intend to repair mine next month and will follow your lead. I sent you a PM.
This is one noisy dryer!
Mine sure was too. The reason the bearings were bad on my unit was because when they were pressed on the commutator shaft, the press pushed against the bearing race dust cover instead of against the inner ring of the bearing. I could see the square indents marked on the dust cover. These bearings are quite tight on the shaft and need to be pressed on carefully. If you don't have a press, and the right puller to pull them off, I'm sure a local machine shop could do the job in about 5 minutes.

On the way home from the southwest this spring, my Winegard Trav'ler antenna would not retract completely to the stow position. After trying repeated re-calibrations, I had to use the manual retract system. A call to Winegard got an obnoxious technician who would only recite a canned script that said I had an out of date system that was out of production. When I asked if parts were available, she refused to answer and would only read the script. The bottom line was that I was to get the unit down from the roof, pay postage to send it to Winegard and then they would tell me if they even had parts to repair it. I had already disassembled it enough to know the elevation motor was the problem. That was the last straw with Winegard.
After a post on a few RV forums, I was directed to RF Mogul. A couple of calls got me the a WEB site and I ordered one. All parts are available to this antenna and servicing seems very easy and straight foward. I finished installing mine today and am very pleased. THe antenna is light, very sturdy, easy to install and works great. For anyone interested in a great alternative to dealing with an obnoxious Winegard company, there is a solution. Contact them. https://rfmogul.com/index.html

Chris at StoneVos was able to quickly fabricate new material for my Monaco Slide Toppers, plus provide replacement support arms (that are no longer available from the OEM). Saved the day (and a vacation) for me!

I've been busy the last few weeks.
Had a bad air leak. Traced it to the right rear air bag. Oxidation of the rubber had allowed chips of rubber to break loose where the bag has sharp bends in it. Records indicate that the bags are original, so nearly 20 years. Replaced both rear bags. Not a terrible job, but requires heavy duty jackstands to make sure you don't get crushed. The fronts are just as chipped, but aren't leaking. Yet. No leaks in the system now.
The chassis AC was inop when I bought it, so I got after it. I didn't want to put a bunch of freon in it just to diagnose any leaks, so I decided to shotgun the compressor, receiver/drier, and expansion valve
. Judging by the compressor and idler pulleys, it looks like the compressor froze up and the belt melted over the pulleys. Decided to break each component apart and flush everything. That's when I found out that the evaporator/heater core box on the front wall was falling apart. The flange screws had been driven in so hard the plastic flange broke. I reinforced the flange with sheet metal, front and back, held on with marine adhesive sealant. Then put in new foam, cleaned up the fins and flushed the evaporator. The box and compressor are installed, but I haven't yet flushed the lines and condenser, but getting there.
And then some easy stuff; fuel filters, belts, kitchen and bathroom faucets.

Purchased a n841 norcold (early 90s model) and a 400 watt onan generator off of our local classified ads for 250 bucks for the set. Fridge ran on ac when I brought it home, have not checked it on propane yet. Trying to decide if I swap out my norcold n621 with the 841. Have not bench tested the onan yet although I did stop by Cummins and pick up 2 new spark plugs
and wires for it

I installed a (mostly) wireless unit, it is not particularly great, but is an improvement over the old one (better resolution, brighter display, better color accuracy, ...). This is the one I bought https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B00WR6ZX84/ though I bought it as an Amazon warehouse open box deal item for $50 which greatly improved the bang for the buck ratio. It does still suffer from some interference and appears to use an analog signal, where the newer units use a digital signal, though they tend to sell for $180+.
This unit also has inputs for 2 wired side view cameras, and possibly an optional forward viewing wireless camera, although I can't find a part number for it. Overall the build quaility on the camera and monitor is better than the old no name brand ones I had. Though the camera looks almost identical to the old one at a distance, it is obvious on closer inspection that the housing and mount are built much better, with thicker steel, allen head screws vs Phillips head, detents on the metal to hold in position, etc.

I sanded and painted the basement box on my slide out behind the left front wheel. The basements come out with slide room and after debris had hit the box, rust was starting to form. Removed the step cover to discover it was starting to rust, threw away the cover and repainted the step. Pulled the fireplace out to see if I could fix the rattle that happens when running the fan. Didn't find anything but lubed up where the rod was going through a support.
I tried to see if I could get the red LED going to the A/C mounted solar panel to work. Fuse was good but it has never worked. Talked to Fleetwood and they said don't worry with it, it is basically useless.
Vacuumed the interior, dusted all the flat surfaces, and wiped down the seats. I will be washing it in about a week before our next outing.

My repair was to my door Dometic awning. Last time out it seemed to be hanging a little low in the front corner. At home in the shed I could give it a good inspection and noticed the pin the front arm pivots on was not pressed down into the bottom tab of the bracket at all, causing the arm to hang low. Actually the top of the pin was so high that a crease was starting to develop in the fabric as the awning extended or retracted. I supported the extended awning from the shed frame while I took the arm off the side of the coach so the pin could be pressed all the way in with a "C" clamp. On further inspection all the pins needed to be pressed in completely. Couldn't find any instructions on specific adjustments so did best I could and seems to work great.

Just replaced the gaskets and ball in my Thetford electric toilet...it no longer held water and I was tired of seeing it dry when I went to use it Not a job for the totally faint at heart because there was some stuff down there that might have been there for 10 years! I cleaned everything and greased some moving parts. It sure is nice knowing I am good for another 10 years!

Scoured the roof and picked up materials for a recoat. Pulled the generator to replace a bad front rotor bearing. Also replacing brushes, filters, plugs, and, unfortunately, the coil. Welded up the cross brace between the forward jacks. Just a couple more things and Iâ€™ll be ready for a road trip.

I just finished rebuilding the sway bar with all new bushings on our '04 Itasca Horizon 36GD with the C-7 330HP CAT. The coach is now 14 years old and it's sporting 83,000 miles. So, when I lost one of those sway bar bushings
, and that created a whole bunch of noise, it was time to rebuild it. Pics below. That being done, it was time to move on with the major project of fabrication of new valances for all the windows. I'd already done 4 of the front section of the coach and, I had two more to finish up. The original ones, while they looked good, were way too flimsy for re-upholstering.
So, I built all new valances and, foamed them then, we (the CEO and I) sewed up new materials and designs for them. We also had the couch done too in some of the same material. The dated coach is now coming into the 22nd century. Waaaaaaay better.
Scott

I finally pinned myself down to have a closer look at my Attwood WH that would not stay ignited. It worked when we first got the MH and declined to were it would kick off seconds after being fired up.
We have motoraid so no problem wallydocking as we usually clean up the night before. We have always stayed at 50A locations but have a spot booked in Myrtle Beach that is only 30A which is smoother if the water heater can run on gas.
Anyway I found the connections on the board corroded and the molux connector pins corroded. Cleaned those up the best I could without removing the pins and cleaned the board connections.
Found the board sealed in resin on a 2004 model that mentioned to check for bad traces on the board. I imagine its been replaced at some point.
Interesting to see it sealed probably to protect it from the elements. I worked for Rockford Fosgate
in the 80s and they sealed their boards in resin and silica sand to hopefully prevent other companies from stealing their tech. Hadn't thought about it in forever until seeing this board jogged the memory loose. I would bet their stuff is no longer hand made in the good ole USA.
Anyway, I digress. I put it all together and flipped the switch and it did absolutely nothing. I was like hmmm. Not intermittent anymore. Waited a few minutes and nothing. Even had a shower to run the water out of the tank with the 115 element off and nothing. Not even a click of the gas valve.
My little voice to the rescue. It told me to close it up and wish it a safe trip home and it will probably work when we get there. Lo and behold, flip the switch and it doesn't do anything. Wait about 10 seconds and it bursts into life and stayed on for quite a while before I cut it off. Im thinking about ordering an eco board and flame sensor just in case. The flame sensor was pretty cruddy.
I also need to replace the release valve. It drips under pressure.

Replaced the left side windscreen, as well as 6 of the underbay hatch struts
. Plan on new front privacy curtains.

01 pseries workhorse 8.1L coolant temp sensor....hard cold start. - replaced three wire sensor was causing hard cold start.....squirting fuel down throttle throat and motor would start right up indicated lean fuel trim. Evidently sensor was telling ECM engine was warm when it was actually cold.
Its on passenger side thru tire well....used 22mm open end wrench move fast and u barely lose any coolant.
Standard Motor Parts TX102 from amazon......they say its wrong part but they are WRONG....86$.

Quote:
Originally Posted by mike brez
Not yet but I'm guessing it was the missing peices of the gasket.
Going to air test the air charge cooler tomorrow then remove the bottom hose to see if anything is laying around that area.
That missing part of gasket will have gone out. That is on the exhaust side anyway.
Your compressor side probably was damaged long before the gasket went. It doesn't take much to do the damage it has. You will likely see a real improvement in power and economy after you replace the turbo.
I have seen damage like that many times from some little bits that got into the clean side of the intake system
somehow.
Just be sure to clean all the piping between the air filter and turbo. Remember, cleanliness is next to godliness in your intake system
.
Happy Glamping.

Fixed a weld that popped on the 1/4" rod that keeps both sides of our fold out steps aligned.. I stepped onto the lower step and heard a loud pop and found the weld that fixed the rod to the side plate had let go.. Used a small oxy/acetylene torch kit with some brazing rod and had it working like new in about 15 minutes.
God I love easy fixes!!

Replaced the multifunction gauge on my freightliner chassis last year. No aftermarket matching gauges exist that I could find. I have been lucky in the past and found manufactures names or part numbers on parts because freightliner has parts made for them by other companies but no luck with the gauge. Ours has the 2 way frig mounted in the slide. It's gone 16 plus years just fine but I noticed on our last trip, that the condenser cooling fan
was running more often than normal. Got home and climbed up to check for obstructions through the upper hatch. Found the fins to be a bit dirty and surface rusted so cleaned them up. Had one dirt dauber nest on one end and removed it.
I also noticed there was a metal deflector installed to focus air flow over the coil. There was a large gap though, about 2 inches wide, that I'm fairly certain was allowing too much air flow to bypass the coil. Unscrewed, drilled out the pop rivets, then reinstalled with less gap to concentrate more air flow over the coil. Thinking this will help to make cooling more efficient in the hot weather we sometimes have to endure.

It rained like all get out for the last two days and I sprung a leak around the air conditioner in the bedroom. DW was not happy to wake up in the middle of the night with water dripping on her head! I took the cover off and tightened the 4 bolts down holding it to the roof. Hopefully this will fix the problem. It's supposed to rain again in the next few days. Keeping my fingers crossed!
I also got up on the roof and put some Eternabond on a couple of small cracks I saw up there which I'm sure was not the cause of the major leak we had. Put some Dicor around the base of the air conditioner as well while I was up there.

Had trouble with my brakes keeping the air pressure up. I replaced air dryer first then the governor with no results. So I thought must be compressor so I got the top end kit. I took it apart and found a piece broken and replaced it.
Started it up and pressure went up great so I thought I had fixed it, not so quick. After about twenty miles down the road air pressure dropped without even using the air Sooo back to work.
I pulled the top of the compressor back off and everything was fineðŸ˜•. I figured out that while it was cooled off it would pump up but would not stay up. So I decided to get another governor this time I bought one from Bendix ( the mfg.) of the compressor and not an off brand. That was the problem. I was lucky because all this happened about twenty miles from home.
Just a heads up on this problem.

Quote:
Originally Posted by Jbertram2
Iâ€™ve replace both of the thermostats Still no heat
Not much to go on...There is in most RV water
heaters, a thermal fuse. It's under the outside access plate. It's covered with a black sleeve. A little bullet shaped device that fails seemingly at random and shuts down the WH. It's obvious when you try to ohm it out. It should read zero but when bad will read 1. Or infinity depending on meter.
I believe the output wire from it is purple and goes to a 1/4" terminal on the ESI board. Check for 12 volt there. If it's zero volt, the thermal fuse is bad.
The printing on the fuse give enough info to google it. Amazon and eBay carry them. So do most electrical supply places. So do RV stores.
This all assumes you usually try to heat your water with propane. But if the thermal fuse is bad, some ESI control boards will shut off the electric element relay too.

Quote:
Originally Posted by MikeGee
Just installed qty 2 new Group 31 chassis batteries. Now working on air dryer that is purging too frequently. Have replaced the dryer filter and rebuilt the lower end (valves) with Haldex kit. Will start looking for / chasing leaks at this point. This rig has pretty much been my retirement project for a year or so. Keeps me broke and out of trouble. ;-)
Air dryer cycling issues are almost never caused by the air dryer. Every time the compressor unloads the dryer purges. Find out why the system won't hold pressure and your cycling issue will be cured.
OTOH, rebuilding the dryer can't hurt anything.
If you don't find an external leak start testing valves.

Many times the leaks are in the 1/4 " lines between the dryer, governor and wet tank. If the governor is remote mounted, there is one more line to check.
The air pressure gauges don't monitor the wet tank, so the leak could be undetected while in the cab.
In a few cases, I've temporarily installed a air gauge in the drain valve port of the wet tank to check the lines for leaks.
The wet tank will be one end of the longer air tank with 2 drains. Look for the seam around it. The wet tank will be the shorter section.

I was a service manager and was lucky enough to go to the dealer show every year at Louisville. This show is not open to the public. It is for dealers only. All the representatives from the different manufacturers are there. This includes the tire manufacturers. ALL the manufacturers said there tires were good for ten years. Where does the 5 to 7 years come from? The tire dealers. They are wanting to sell more tires. I will go with the manufacturers recommendation every time. The funny thing is, according to the manufacturers, your chance of a tire failure is with a new tire. If a tire is built bad it will fail fairly soon. If it lasts several years, it was built to specs and will be good for ten years.
